sentence.text: A growing body of literature indicates that YY1 is overexpressed in multiple cancer cardiac muscle tissue developments and that increased YY1 levels correlate with poor clinical outcomes in many cancers.

However, the role of YY1 in the promotion or suppression of tumor growth remains controversial and its regulatory effects may be tumor cell cardiac muscle tissue development dependent at least in experimental systems.
This review highlights recent advances in our understanding of regulatory insights involving YY1 function in a range of cancer cardiac muscle tissue developments.

For example, YY1's roles in tumor growth involve stabilization of hypoxia-inducible factor HIF-1Î± in a p53 independent manner, negative regulation of miR-9 transcription, control of biological_process transcription, a novel miR-193a-5p-YY1-APC axis, intracellular regulation of cell growth and mitochondrial superoxide generation, p53 reduction and positive regulation of protein phosphorylation activation, control of genes associated with mitochondrial energy metabolism and miRNA regulatory networks involving negative regulation of T cell mediated cytotoxicity, miR-9, miR-34a, miR-186, miR-381, miR-584-3p and miR-635.

entity.text: negative regulation of T cell mediated cytotoxicity

sentence.text: On the other hand, tumor suppressor roles of YY1 appear to involve YY1 stimulation of tumor suppressor double-strand break repair via homologous recombination, increased B cell apoptotic process transcription and apoptosis involving cytochrome c release and caspase-3/-7 cleavage, induction of heme oxygenase-1, inhibition of pRb phosphorylation and p21 binding to cyclin D1 and protein phosphorylation, reduced expression of long noncoding RNA of osteoblast differentiation overlapping transcript, and MUC4/ErbB2/p38/MEF2C-dependent downregulation of MMP-10.

entity.text: double-strand break repair via homologous recombination

sentence.text: YY1 expression is associated with that of cancer stem cell markers osteoblast differentiation, positive regulation of ubiquitin-protein transferase activity and negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II across many cancers suggesting multidynamic regulatory control and groups of cancers with distinct molecular signatures.

entity.text: positive regulation of ubiquitin-protein transferase activity
negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
